lessons.title: Science Practice Set — Reading, Experiments, Numbers (33 Questions)

content.text: Reading Q1 — Passage 1

A researcher observed two ponds located a mile apart. Pond A is shaded by trees and receives nutrient runoff from nearby gardens. Pond B is in full sun and has no nearby gardens. During the summer, Pond A developed a thick layer of algae, while Pond B remained relatively clear. The researcher measured dissolved oxygen and found that Pond A showed large daily swings, with very low levels just before sunrise. Pond B showed smaller swings and maintained higher minimum oxygen levels.
Q1a — Which factor most likely explains the algae growth in Pond A?

items: A) Pond A receives more wind than Pond B
B) Nutrient runoff from gardens feeds algal growth
C) The ponds are one mile apart
D) Pond A has fewer fish

content.text: Answer: B — Nutrient runoff increases available nitrogen and phosphorus that fuel algae.
Q1b — Why are oxygen levels in Pond A lowest just before sunrise?

items: A) Photosynthesis is highest at night
B) Respiration by organisms continues overnight while photosynthesis stops in the dark
C) Oxygen dissolves better in warm water at night
D) Wind stops at night, increasing oxygen

content.text: Answer: B — Without light, photosynthesis stops but respiration continues, lowering oxygen by dawn.
Q1c — Which statement best expresses the passage’s central idea?

items: A) All ponds stay clear in summer
C) Nutrient input and light exposure affect algal growth and oxygen dynamics
D) Ponds a mile apart are identical

content.text: Answer: C — The observations connect nutrients and light to algae and oxygen swings.
Reading Q2 — Passage 2

A school tested an after‑school study program. Volunteers joined a 6‑week program that provided quiet space, tutors, and structured breaks. Participants’ average test scores increased by 8 points compared to their previous scores. Nonparticipants’ average scores increased by 3 points over the same period. The study did not randomly assign students. Many volunteers already reported high motivation to improve their grades.
Q2a — Which conclusion is most supported by the results?

items: A) The program caused all students to score higher than nonparticipants
B) The program is correlated with larger score gains among volunteers
C) The program had no effect on learning
D) Random assignment confirmed the program’s effect

content.text: Answer: B — Results show an association; causation is not proven without random assignment.
Q2b — Which limitation most weakens a causal claim?

items: A) The program lasted six weeks
C) Participation was not randomized and volunteers reported high motivation
D) The school provided structured breaks

content.text: Answer: C — Self‑selection and preexisting motivation introduce confounding.
Q2c — What is the author’s purpose in including both groups’ gains?

items: A) To show that only nonparticipants improved
B) To compare changes and suggest the program may help
C) To prove the program works for every student

content.text: Answer: B — The comparison suggests a possible benefit but does not prove causation.
Reading Q3 — Vocabulary in context (Passage 1): “swings” most nearly means:
Answer: B — Here, swings refers to large daily changes in dissolved oxygen.
Reading Q4 — Which detail best supports the claim that light influences oxygen levels in ponds?

items: A) The ponds are one mile apart
B) Pond B had higher minimum oxygen and smaller daily swings
C) Pond A is shaded by trees

content.text: Answer: C — Shade reduces photosynthesis, contributing to lower overnight oxygen in Pond A.
Reading Q5 — Which statement is an inference from Passage 2?

items: A) Motivation may partly explain volunteers’ larger gains
B) Tutors guaranteed success for all
D) The program lasted for a full year

content.text: Answer: A — The passage suggests motivated volunteers may improve more regardless of the program.
Design Q6 — Identify variables
A lab tests how fertilizer concentration affects bean plant height over 4 weeks.

items: A) Independent variable: plant height; dependent: fertilizer concentration
B) Independent variable: fertilizer concentration; dependent: plant height
C) Independent variable: time only; dependent: sunlight
D) Independent variable: soil mass; dependent: water pH

content.text: Answer: B — The researcher changes fertilizer concentration and measures height.
Design Q7 — Controls and constants
Which is the best control setup?

items: A) Plants with 0% fertilizer, same soil, water, and light as other groups
B) Plants with 10% fertilizer and different soil
D) Plants with 0% fertilizer but watered twice as often

content.text: Answer: A — Control receives 0% fertilizer with all other conditions constant.
Design Q8 — Sample size and replication
Which choice strengthens reliability the most?

items: B) Use 10 plants per treatment and repeat the experiment

content.text: Answer: B — Larger sample size and replication reduce random error.
Design Q9 — Blinding and placebo
In a headache study, which design reduces bias?

items: A) Open‑label test with caffeine tablets only
B) Single‑blind test with caffeine vs. sugar pill
D) Unlabeled herbal teas with different flavors

content.text: Answer: B — A placebo control with blinding reduces expectation bias.
Design Q10 — Operational definition
Which definition is most measurable?

items: A) Plants are healthy if they look nice
B) Plant health is the number of leaves per plant after 21 days
C) Plants are healthy if they are green
D) Plants are healthy if they are tall

content.text: Answer: B — A countable measure provides clarity and repeatability.
Design Q11 — Hypotheses and predictions
Which is a testable prediction?

items: A) Adding 2% salt to water will reduce seed germination by at least 20% compared to fresh water

content.text: Answer: A — It is specific, measurable, and comparative.
Design Q12 — Confounding variables
A sleep study adds blue‑light filters but also changes bedtime. Which is confounded?

items: A) Light color and bedtime both changed

content.text: Answer: A — Two variables changed, confounding effects.
Design Q13 — Data quality
Which practice best reduces measurement error for lab mass readings?

items: A) Use a balance with appropriate precision and calibrate it
B) Use a kitchen scale for all samples
C) Round masses to the nearest 10 g
D) Measure once per week only

content.text: Answer: A — Calibration and proper precision reduce error.
Design Q14 — Ethics in experiments
Which action aligns with ethical research?

items: A) Not informing participants about risks
D) Discarding data that do not fit hypotheses

content.text: Answer: B — Respect for persons, informed consent, and confidentiality are key.
Design Q15 — Interpreting conclusions
A study finds a correlation between screen time and lower sleep. The best conclusion is:

items: A) Screen time causes poor sleep in all cases
B) There is an association; experiments are needed to test causation
C) Sleep causes more screen time

content.text: Answer: B — Correlation alone does not establish causation.
Design Q16 — Reproducibility
Which change best improves reproducibility?

items: A) Provide detailed procedures and share data
C) Use unique instruments no one else has

content.text: Answer: A — Detailed methods and open data enable replication.
Numbers Q17 — Mean and median
Answer: A — Mean (3+7+7+9+14)/5 = 40/5 = 8; median is 7.

Numbers Q19 — Percent change
A value increases from 60 to 75. Percent change is:
Numbers Q20 — Slope from a data table
Time (s): 2, 5; Distance (m): 8, 20. Slope (m/s) is:
Numbers Q21 — Unit conversion
Convert 450 mL to liters.
Answer: B — 1000 mL = 1 L; 450 mL = 0.45 L.
Numbers Q22 — Significant figures
Multiply 2.40 cm × 3.1 cm. Record with correct significant figures.
Answer: B — Result 7.44, but limited to 2 significant figures (3.1) → 7.4 cm^2.
Numbers Q23 — Reading a bar chart (table given)
Species counts: oak = 12, pine = 7, maple = 9. Which species is most common and what percent of total is it?
Answer: B — Total = 12+7+9 = 28; oak 12/28 ≈ 42.9% ≈ 43%; closest choice 44%.
Numbers Q24 — Density by hand
A sample has mass 18 g and volume 6 cm^3. Density is:
Answer: A — 18/6 = 3 g/cm^3.
Numbers Q25 — Interpreting a line graph (table given)
Temperature (°C): 10, 15, 20; Solubility (g/100 mL): 20, 28, 37. The best description is:

items: A) Solubility decreases as temperature increases
C) Solubility increases with temperature at an increasing rate
D) Solubility increases with temperature at a decreasing rate

content.text: Answer: C — Differences are +8 then +9, suggesting a slightly increasing rate.
Numbers Q26 — Proportional reasoning
If 5 mL of indicator is needed for 8 tests, how much is needed for 20 tests?
Design Q27 — Reading methods
A paper states, “We used randomized blocks by classroom.” What does this control?

items: A) Differences among classrooms as a confounding factor

content.text: Answer: A — Blocking by classroom accounts for classroom‑level differences.
Reading Q28 — Interpreting claims
An ad claims a supplement “supports focus” based on an uncontrolled study. Best interpretation is:

items: C) Weak evidence; lack of control limits conclusions
D) Proof that no benefit exists

content.text: Answer: C — Without controls and randomization, conclusions are limited.
Design Q29 — Graph choice
Which graph best displays a relationship between temperature (°C) and enzyme rate (units/s)?

items: B) Scatter plot with a trend line

content.text: Answer: B — Two quantitative variables → scatter plot.
Numbers Q30 — Median from frequency table
Heights (cm): 150(2), 155(3), 160(4), 165(1). What is the median?
Answer: B — Data size = 10; median is average of 5th and 6th values, both 160.
Numbers Q31 — Error and uncertainty
A length is 12.0 ± 0.1 cm. Which is a reasonable range?
Answer: A — The ± value indicates an interval around the measured value.
Design Q32 — Negative controls
In a microbial culture test, which is a negative control?

items: A) Plate inoculated with sterile water
C) Plate with nutrient agar and bacteria

content.text: Answer: A — Sterile water should yield no growth, verifying sterility.
Reading Q33 — Author’s tone
A report neutrally describes methods and results, notes limitations, and suggests further study. The tone is:
Answer: B — The tone is informational and objective.
